symptoms: Dark, scabby lesions primarily on the upper surface of leaves and fruit skin
Premature leaf drop, leading to weakened trees
Olive-green to black velvety spots on leaves and young shoots
Deformed, cracked, and discolored fruit
Reduced fruit size and quality
causes: Fungal spores (Venturia inaequalis) overwinter in fallen leaves and fruit debris
Spread occurs primarily through wind-driven rain during spring and early summer
Infection is favored by prolonged leaf wetness and temperatures between 55–75°F (13–24°C)
High humidity environments encourage the rapid development of the disease
Neglecting orchard sanitation increases inoculum for the next season
prevention: Plant resistant apple cultivars whenever possible
Prune trees to improve air circulation and sunlight penetration
Rake and destroy fallen leaves and fruit to reduce overwintering spores
Apply protective fungicide sprays starting from early bud break throughout the growing season
Implement proper irrigation practices to avoid excessive leaf wetness
Use mulches to minimize soil splash onto leaves during rain
cure: Remove and destroy infected leaves, fruits, and branches during the growing season
Apply systemic and protective fungicides like captan, mancozeb, or myclobutanil as per agricultural extension guidelines
Perform regular monitoring and early intervention upon first signs of infection
Improve tree vigor through proper fertilization and watering to enhance natural resistance
Consider using organic fungicides such as sulfur-based products for eco-friendly control

symptoms: Black, sunken lesions with concentric ring patterns on fruit ('frog-eye' spots)
Small purple spots on leaves that expand into large necrotic areas
Twigs may show cankers, causing dieback
Shriveled, mummified fruits remain attached to the tree
Fruits rot internally and emit a foul odor at later stages
causes: Fungal pathogen Botryosphaeria obtusa survives in cankers, dead wood, and mummified fruits
Rain splash disperses fungal spores to healthy tissues
Wounds and insect injuries on fruit provide entry points
High temperatures and humid conditions increase severity
Neglected orchard sanitation promotes disease persistence
prevention: Prune and remove all dead wood and infected branches annually
Ensure good orchard sanitation by removing mummified fruits
Apply protective fungicides during bloom and fruit development stages
Use resistant apple varieties when available
Avoid mechanical injuries to trees during mowing or harvesting
cure: Apply fungicides such as captan or thiophanate-methyl at early signs
Cut out cankers at least 6 inches below visible symptoms
Improve drainage and avoid overwatering
Maintain tree health with balanced nutrition to reduce susceptibility
Consider biological controls like Trichoderma-based products

symptoms: Bright yellow-orange spots form on the upper surface of apple leaves.
Spots enlarge and may develop tube-like projections underneath leaves.
Fruit may develop small, deformed, and blemished areas, leading to poor quality.
Premature leaf drop and reduced fruit yield.
Leaves may curl or become distorted under heavy infections.
causes: Caused by the fungus Gymnosporangium juniperi-virginianae.
Fungus needs two hosts: apple trees and cedar/juniper trees to complete its life cycle.
Spores are produced on cedar trees in early spring and travel by wind to infect apple trees.
Wet and warm conditions favor spore release and infection.
prevention: Remove nearby cedar or juniper trees within a 2–5 mile radius if possible.
Choose resistant apple varieties such as Liberty and Freedom.
Apply preventive fungicides starting at the pink bud stage through to the petal fall.
Prune trees regularly to promote good airflow and reduce moisture.
Avoid planting susceptible apple varieties near cedar trees.
cure: Apply systemic fungicides like myclobutanil or propiconazole during early stages.
Remove and destroy infected leaves or fruit.
Prune galls from cedar trees during winter to break the disease cycle.
Increase tree health with proper fertilization and irrigation.

symptoms: A white, powdery fungal growth appears on young leaves, shoots, and sometimes fruit.
Leaves may curl, twist, and become discolored.
Severely infected leaves may fall off prematurely.
Shoots may be stunted, and fruit development can be negatively affected.
Fine web-like fungal growth visible under humid conditions.
causes: Caused by the fungus Podosphaera clandestina.
Spores spread through air currents and infect young, actively growing tissues.
Dry, warm days with humid nights favor the disease.
Dense canopies with poor air circulation enhance the risk.
prevention: Prune trees to open canopies and improve air circulation.
Water trees at soil level rather than overhead to keep foliage dry.
Choose resistant varieties where available.
Apply sulfur-based or systemic fungicides preventively.
Avoid excessive nitrogen fertilization that promotes lush, susceptible growth.
cure: Apply fungicides like sulfur, myclobutanil, or potassium bicarbonate.
Prune and remove heavily infected shoots and leaves immediately.
Dispose of infected plant material far away from the orchard.
Repeat fungicide sprays if humid conditions persist.

symptoms: Long, narrow, rectangular gray to tan lesions on leaves with dark borders.
Lesions may coalesce, causing large dead patches on leaves.
Reduced photosynthesis leading to stunted plant growth.
Severe infections may cause leaves to die prematurely.
Yield loss due to less grain fill and poor ear development.
causes: Caused by the fungus Cercospora zeae-maydis.
Fungal spores overwinter in corn debris left on the field surface.
Spores are spread by wind and rain splash during warm, humid conditions.
High humidity and leaf wetness for over 12 hours promote infection.
prevention: Practice crop rotation with non-host crops like soybeans.
Use disease-resistant corn hybrids.
Bury crop debris by deep tillage to reduce spore survival.
Maintain adequate plant spacing to promote airflow and reduce humidity.
Apply fungicides at the VT (tasseling) stage if disease pressure is high.
cure: Use fungicides such as strobilurins or triazoles early in disease development.
Scout fields regularly to catch infections early.
Remove infected debris after harvest.
Implement integrated pest management strategies.

symptoms: Reddish-brown pustules develop on both upper and lower leaf surfaces.
Pustules may merge, causing larger areas of dead tissue.
Infected leaves may yellow and dry up prematurely.
Severe infection can cause reduced photosynthesis and stunted growth.
Ears may be smaller and poorly filled if infection is early.
causes: Caused by the fungus Puccinia sorghi.
Spores are spread by wind over long distances.
Infection favored by moist, cool to moderately warm temperatures (60-77°F).
Heavy dew and extended periods of leaf wetness accelerate disease spread.
prevention: Plant resistant corn hybrids adapted to local conditions.
Implement crop rotation to break the disease cycle.
Maintain proper field sanitation by removing volunteer corn plants.
Plant early to avoid peak spore arrival times.
cure: Apply fungicides like azoxystrobin or propiconazole at early disease stages.
Scout fields regularly to identify infections early.
Remove infected crop residues after harvest to reduce overwintering spores.
Optimize plant density to promote airflow.

symptoms: Large, cigar-shaped, tan to gray lesions form on leaves.
Lesions often start on lower leaves and move upward.
Infected leaves may die, reducing photosynthesis.
Plants may appear drought-stressed even with adequate soil moisture.
Significant yield loss if infection occurs before or during flowering.
causes: Caused by the fungus Exserohilum turcicum.
Spores overwinter in corn debris and are spread by wind and rain.
Infection favored by cool, moist weather (64–80°F).
High humidity and prolonged leaf wetness promote disease development.
prevention: Plant resistant or tolerant corn varieties.
Rotate crops to non-host species like soybeans or alfalfa.
Plow under or remove infected debris to limit overwintering spores.
Apply fungicides as a preventive measure when conditions favor infection.
cure: Use fungicides containing strobilurins, triazoles, or SDHI groups.
Scout early and frequently during critical growth stages (V8 to R1).
Optimize nutrient management to enhance plant vigor.
Avoid continuous corn planting in high-risk areas.

symptoms: Tiny black spots on leaves that enlarge and develop tan centers.
Dark, shriveled, and mummified fruit hanging on the vine.
Circular lesions with black margins on stems and shoots.
Fruit rot results in complete crop loss if not controlled.
Leaf spots sometimes have small black fungal structures (pycnidia) in them.
causes: Caused by the fungus Guignardia bidwellii.
Overwinters in mummified fruit and infected shoots.
Spread by splashing rain and wind during wet, warm periods.
Infection most severe during humid, rainy weather in late spring and early summer.
prevention: Remove and destroy all mummified fruit and infected plant parts.
Apply fungicides preventively, especially before wet periods.
Prune vines to improve sunlight penetration and air circulation.
Choose disease-tolerant grape varieties where possible.
cure: Spray fungicides like captan, myclobutanil, or mancozeb at regular intervals.
Remove infected fruits and leaves immediately to reduce inoculum.
Maintain a well-balanced fertilization program to encourage healthy growth.
Use cultural practices combined with chemical control for best results.

symptoms: Interveinal yellowing and browning of leaves, often with tiger-stripe patterns.
Black spots and streaks appear on the wood and trunk (wood decay).
Berries may shrivel, darken, and split open, emitting a sour odor.
Sudden wilting and vine collapse in hot weather.
Reduced fruit yield and vine vigor over time.
causes: Caused by a complex of fungi including Phaeomoniella chlamydospora and Fomitiporia mediterranea.
Infection enters through pruning wounds.
Spores spread by rain splash and contaminated pruning tools.
Dry, stressed vines are more susceptible to infection.
prevention: Avoid pruning during wet weather to minimize infection risk.
Seal pruning wounds with wound protectants or fungicides.
Use healthy, disease-free planting material.
Implement proper vineyard sanitation and remove infected vines.
cure: There is no complete cure once a vine is heavily infected.
Prune and remove infected wood early to slow disease progression.
Apply fungicides that protect pruning wounds.
Maintain vine vigor through proper irrigation, fertilization, and pest control.

symptoms: Brown, irregular spots form on leaves, often near leaf margins.
Spots may enlarge and merge, causing large dead areas.
Severely infected leaves may fall prematurely, reducing vine strength.
Black fungal fruiting bodies may develop in dead tissue under humid conditions.
Yield reduction due to fewer healthy leaves for photosynthesis.
causes: Caused by the fungus Pseudocercospora vitis (formerly Isariopsis clavispora).
Spores spread by rain splash and wind.
High humidity and frequent rain events favor disease development.
Dense canopy and poor airflow increase risk of infection.
prevention: Prune vines to open up canopy and improve air circulation.
Avoid overhead irrigation that keeps foliage wet.
Apply preventive fungicides at early growth stages.
Remove and destroy infected leaves and debris after harvest.
cure: Use fungicides like mancozeb or copper-based sprays.
Scout regularly to catch early signs of infection.
Improve drainage in the vineyard to reduce humidity levels.
Combine cultural practices with chemical treatments for effective control.

symptoms: Yellowing of shoots and asymmetric blotchy mottling on leaves.
Small, lopsided, bitter fruits that stay green at the bottom.
Twig dieback and overall tree decline.
Leaf veins may become thickened and corky.
Premature fruit drop and tree death in severe cases.
causes: Caused by the bacterium Candidatus Liberibacter, transmitted by Asian citrus psyllid.
Bacteria block nutrient flow inside the tree.
Spread is accelerated by movement of infected plant material.
Favored by warm climates where psyllid populations thrive.
prevention: Use certified disease-free nursery trees.
Control psyllid populations using insecticides and biological controls.
Remove and destroy infected trees promptly to prevent spread.
Implement area-wide management programs involving all growers.
cure: No cure currently exists.
Manage symptoms by maintaining tree health with proper nutrition and irrigation.
Apply antibacterial treatments like oxytetracycline (injection) where allowed.
Research ongoing into resistant rootstocks and gene-editing solutions.

symptoms: Small, dark, water-soaked spots on leaves and fruits.
Leaf spots become angular and may drop out, creating 'shot holes.'
Fruits develop rough, cracked, sunken lesions.
Twig cankers may develop in severe infections.
Premature leaf drop reduces tree vigor.
causes: Caused by the bacterium Xanthomonas arboricola pv. pruni.
Bacteria spread by rain splash and wind-driven rain.
Infections favored by warm, wet weather during spring and early summer.
Wounds and natural openings serve as infection sites.
prevention: Plant resistant peach varieties if available.
Prune trees to improve air circulation and drying of foliage.
Apply copper-based bactericides preventively, especially before rainy periods.
Avoid excessive nitrogen fertilization which promotes tender, susceptible growth.
cure: There is no cure once symptoms appear.
Manage spread by removing severely infected twigs.
Apply copper sprays during dormant and growing seasons to limit spread.
Maintain tree health to improve resistance to infection.

symptoms: Water-soaked, dark lesions on leaves, stems, and fruits.
Leaf lesions may turn brown and crack, leading to leaf drop.
Fruit lesions are raised, rough, and corky.
Severe infection leads to defoliation and yield loss.
Bacterial ooze may be visible under humid conditions.
causes: Caused by the bacterium Xanthomonas campestris pv. vesicatoria.
Spread through infected seeds, transplants, and splashing water.
Favored by warm (75–90°F), humid conditions.
Injury to plants through cultivation or insects can facilitate infection.
prevention: Use certified disease-free seeds and transplants.
Rotate crops and avoid planting peppers and tomatoes in the same area consecutively.
Apply copper-based bactericides as preventive treatments.
Manage irrigation to avoid prolonged leaf wetness.
cure: No complete cure once the disease establishes.
Limit spread by removing infected plants early.
Regular copper applications can help suppress bacterial populations.
Implement strict field sanitation practices.

symptoms: Dark, concentric ring lesions (target spots) on older leaves.
Yellowing around lesions and leaf drop.
Stem lesions may occur, leading to weakened plants.
Infected tubers develop sunken, dark lesions under storage conditions.
Yield losses due to reduced foliage and weakened plants.
causes: Caused by the fungus Alternaria solani.
Spores spread by wind, rain, and irrigation water.
Disease favored by warm temperatures (78–86°F) and extended leaf wetness.
Infection starts on stressed or senescing foliage.
prevention: Plant certified, disease-free seed potatoes.
Rotate crops with non-host plants like cereals or legumes.
Apply fungicides preventively, especially during periods of wet weather.
Optimize plant spacing to improve airflow.
cure: Use fungicides like chlorothalonil, mancozeb, or strobilurins early.
Remove and destroy infected plant debris after harvest.
Irrigate in a way that minimizes leaf wetness (drip irrigation).
Maintain balanced fertilization to strengthen plant defenses.

symptoms: Water-soaked, dark lesions on leaves and stems.
Lesions rapidly enlarge, turning brown and necrotic with white moldy growth under humid conditions.
Tuber infections cause firm, brown, granular rot.
Rapid plant collapse and death in severe infections.
Foul odor from rotting tubers during storage.
causes: Caused by the oomycete Phytophthora infestans.
Spores spread by rain, wind, and contaminated equipment.
Favored by cool, wet weather (60–70°F with high humidity).
Infections start from infected seed tubers or volunteer plants.
prevention: Plant resistant varieties where available.
Destroy volunteer potatoes and cull piles.
Apply protective fungicides before infection periods.
Practice crop rotation and proper field sanitation.
cure: Fungicides like chlorothalonil, mancozeb, or cyazofamid can help limit spread.
Rogue out and destroy infected plants immediately.
Avoid overhead irrigation that prolongs leaf wetness.
Monitor weather forecasts and apply fungicides accordingly.

symptoms: No symptoms of disease.
Vigorous plant growth with lush, green leaves.
Healthy fruit development without lesions or discolorations.
Absence of leaf spots, cane blights, or fruit rots.
Uniform color and firmness of berries.
causes: Good cultural practices and environmental conditions.
Proper soil drainage and fertility management.
Use of disease-free planting material.
Effective pest and disease monitoring and control.
prevention: Maintain regular monitoring and preventive care.
Prune to encourage good airflow and reduce humidity.
Water at the base to avoid wetting foliage.
Use mulch to suppress weeds and retain soil moisture.
cure: No cure needed for healthy plants.
Continue preventive practices to maintain plant health.

symptoms: Vigorous, upright plants with uniform leaf color.
No spotting, chlorosis, or wilting observed.
Pods develop normally without deformation or rot.
Roots are white and healthy without lesions.
High yield potential with consistent pod set.
causes: Absence of pathogens and pest pressure.
Good agronomic practices like crop rotation and soil fertility management.
Use of high-quality, certified seeds.
Timely irrigation and pest management.
prevention: Implement regular crop scouting.
Rotate crops to prevent buildup of soilborne pathogens.
Apply balanced fertilization based on soil test recommendations.
Manage weeds, insects, and diseases promptly.
cure: No cure needed for healthy soybean plants.
Maintain vigilant field management to sustain health.

symptoms: White, powdery fungal growth on leaves, stems, and flowers.
Leaves may yellow, curl, and die prematurely.
Reduced fruit quality and yield.
Severe infections can lead to plant death.
Fungal growth often first appears on shaded, older leaves.
causes: Caused by several fungal species, including Podosphaera xanthii and Erysiphe cichoracearum.
Spores spread by wind.
Disease favored by warm, dry days and cool, humid nights.
High nitrogen levels encourage tender, susceptible growth.
prevention: Plant resistant squash varieties.
Ensure good air circulation through proper plant spacing.
Water plants at the base rather than overhead.
Apply preventive fungicides if powdery mildew is common locally.
cure: Apply fungicides like sulfur, potassium bicarbonate, or myclobutanil early.
Remove and destroy heavily infected leaves to reduce spread.
Manage fertilization to avoid excessive nitrogen levels.
Use baking soda sprays as an organic alternative.

symptoms: Small, purple to reddish spots on leaves that enlarge over time.
Spots may merge and cause large dead areas.
Leaves dry out and curl but typically remain attached to the plant.
Severe cases lead to reduced fruit yield and poor plant vigor.
No fungal growth observed on the underside of leaves.
causes: Caused by the fungus Diplocarpon earlianum.
Spread through splashing rain and irrigation water.
Favored by prolonged periods of wet foliage and moderate temperatures.
Overcrowded plantings with poor airflow increase risk.
prevention: Plant resistant varieties if available.
Space plants properly to enhance airflow.
Avoid overhead watering to minimize leaf wetness.
Apply fungicides during early stages of leaf development if needed.
cure: Apply fungicides such as captan or myclobutanil at the first signs.
Remove and destroy infected leaves and debris.
Improve drainage and sunlight exposure.
Combine chemical and cultural methods for effective control.

symptoms: Small, water-soaked spots on leaves, stems, and fruit.
Spots enlarge and turn brown with a yellow halo.
Leaves may become tattered and drop prematurely.
Fruit lesions are raised, rough, and scabby.
Severe infections can cause defoliation and yield loss.
causes: Caused by several species of Xanthomonas bacteria.
Spread through contaminated seeds, tools, and splashing water.
Favored by warm (77–86°F), humid conditions.
Entry through wounds and natural openings.
prevention: Use certified, disease-free seeds and transplants.
Rotate crops and avoid overhead irrigation.
Apply copper-based bactericides preventatively.
Sanitize tools and manage weeds.
cure: No cure once established, focus on preventing spread.
Remove severely infected plants.
Use copper sprays combined with mancozeb for better results.
Maintain good field hygiene practices.

symptoms: Dark brown spots with concentric rings on older leaves ('target spots').
Yellowing around lesions leading to leaf drop.
Fruit can develop dark, sunken lesions at the stem end.
Premature defoliation weakens the plant.
Overall yield and fruit quality decrease.
causes: Caused by the fungus Alternaria solani.
Spores spread by rain splash, wind, and contaminated equipment.
Favored by warm, humid weather.
Often starts on older or stressed leaves.
prevention: Rotate crops away from tomatoes and potatoes.
Use resistant varieties if available.
Apply fungicides preventively when conditions are favorable.
Mulch soil to reduce spore splash.
cure: Fungicide applications (chlorothalonil, mancozeb, or azoxystrobin).
Remove and destroy infected debris.
Optimize plant spacing for airflow.
Water plants at the base.

symptoms: Large, irregular, water-soaked lesions on leaves and stems.
Lesions rapidly turn brown and produce white mold under humid conditions.
Fruits develop greasy, firm, brown lesions.
Rapid plant collapse and death under favorable conditions.
A foul smell from rotting fruits and plant tissue.
causes: Caused by the oomycete Phytophthora infestans.
Spread through rain, wind, and contaminated equipment.
Favored by cool, wet weather (60–70°F).
Initiated from infected transplants or volunteer plants.
prevention: Plant resistant varieties when possible.
Apply fungicides before infection periods.
Destroy infected plants immediately upon detection.
Avoid overhead irrigation and ensure good air circulation.
cure: Use systemic fungicides like cyazofamid or mandipropamid.
Remove and destroy infected plants and fruits.
Practice crop rotation and sanitation.
Monitor weather and apply protective sprays.

symptoms: Pale green or yellow spots on upper leaf surfaces.
Velvety olive-green to gray mold on the underside of leaves.
Leaves curl, wither, and drop off.
Fruit may develop leathery, dark lesions in severe cases.
Disease progression favors greenhouse environments.
causes: Caused by the fungus Passalora fulva (formerly Fulvia fulva).
Spores spread through air, water splash, and contaminated surfaces.
Favored by high humidity (>85%) and moderate temperatures (60–80°F).
Poor air circulation in dense plantings increases risk.
prevention: Grow resistant tomato varieties.
Ventilate greenhouses well and avoid overhead watering.
Apply fungicides preventively if necessary.
Space plants adequately for better airflow.
cure: Use fungicides like chlorothalonil, mancozeb, or copper-based products.
Remove and destroy infected leaves.
Reduce humidity and increase air movement.
Disinfect greenhouse structures regularly.

symptoms: Small, circular spots with dark borders and tan or gray centers on leaves.
Spots often contain tiny black fruiting bodies (pycnidia).
Lower leaves are affected first, leading to yellowing and defoliation.
Fruit infection is rare but plant vigor reduces.
Heavy infections can cause total plant collapse.
causes: Caused by the fungus Septoria lycopersici.
Spread by rain splash, wind, and infected debris.
Favored by warm (68–77°F), wet conditions.
Survives on plant debris and volunteer tomato plants.
prevention: Use certified disease-free seeds and transplants.
Rotate crops and avoid overhead irrigation.
Apply protective fungicides preventively.
Remove infected plant material promptly.
cure: Use fungicides such as chlorothalonil, mancozeb, or copper products.
Maintain good garden hygiene.
Optimize spacing for airflow and quicker drying.
Mulch soil to prevent splash dispersal.
